doc.field: Letter to Chloe Unity Blair [a machine-readable transcription]
Letter to Chloe Unity Blair [a machine-readable transcription]
James and John Booker tend to use commas instead of periods to end a sentence. In the modernized version of this letter, we have regularized punctuation in unambiguous cases.
James and John Booker tend to use commas instead of periods to end a sentence. In the modernized version of this letter, we have regularized punctuation in unambiguous cases.
Manassas junction Oct. 8 th 1861 [1] Dear Cousin

I write afew lines this morning to inform you that I am well at this time and hopeing that it may find you all injoying the same blesing, the health of our company is better at this time than it has bin for some time,

I have no news of intrust to write to you, it is thought that we will have a battle in a few days, its reported that thay was fighting yesterday at fawls Church I dont know weth er it was so or not, one of the Dan ville Grays was upto see us last night he said the yankees was in four miles of them thay are stationed at Farfax Court House six miles a head of us, it is thought that we will have a verry hard battle when it does come off, I received a letter from Addie [2] last eavning it afforded me great pleasure to hear that he was improveing so fast,
I will ad no more at present so good bye write soon to your affectionate Cousin James Booker To Miss C. U. Blair
letter to chloe unity blair a machine readable transcription
